Full-length Formal dress Is Not for You, But Many Others Are

Many girls regret about their statures when they are shopping for a formal dress that is supposed to show the best of them at one of the most important events in their life. Who could resist the temptation of looking graceful in a long formal dress with elegantly decorated skirt? While physical height makes a full-length formal dress an untouchable dream, there are many ways to have the right formal dresses make you an attractive girl regardless of your real stature.

Even if you are not tall enough to fit a full-length formal dress, you can just choose to wear a short formal dress that fits you. By revealing your lower legs or at least the ankles, a formal dress of proper length can shift others’ attention from your height to your overall figure that is no less pretty than tall girls. In order to make sure the dress will indeed give out such effects, you should first of all choose from the formal dresses that reach below to the knee or to the ankle at the most. That is to say, do not let the formal dress fully cover the lower part of your body, otherwise, you will look even shorter worse-proportioned because the real figure shape is hidden and curves are weakened by boring cloth of the long skirt. In order to make your figure look better in the formal dress of the right length, a pair of well-chosen shoes without straps or other ankle-covering ornaments will also help highlight the charming parts of a petite girl.

In addition to length, the design of the 12 year formal dress is also critical to making others feel confused with your actual height. Many girls lacking confidence in their own shape just choose formal dresses loose enough to hide imperfect parts as well as the attractive parts. In fact there are much better ways to turn others’ eyes away from your imperfect parts of shape. High-waist design will give you a visually longer waist that adds to the visual height of your figure, and tight upper part with loose lower part or vice versa also helps exaggerate the better-looking part of your shape and lengthen the overall visual height. It should be noted that it is not necessary to just stick with one design that works for you once, since designs following similar principles will all be good choices for your formal dress.

Similarly to the design, the color of your formal dress should neither just be in plain white or blue. Although contrasting colors in upper and lower parts must be avoided so as to save your visual height from looking “contracted” between the top and the bottom, mixed color patterns can still be used for more vivid appearance. The secret lies in the size of the patterns. While large-size patterns help tall girls gain eye-catching peculiarity, small or tiny colored patterns just make petite girls look sweeter and more appealing in their well-fitting formal dresses, because the contrast between the small patterns and the wearers’ overall figure is another trick to look taller than they virtually are.

A Stain Should Not Ruin the Formal Night

There are many reasons for a girl to wear a formal dress with a stain on the important night. It could be that the stain is irremovable, or that she has no time to get it cleaned up, or that the fabric of the dress requires special treatment which is not available to her. No matter what the reason is, she just has to put it on to attend the formal, because it is not worth it to give up the formal for just a stain on her dress. Surely, she will not just let the stain become what may cause her to be laughed at by others, and there are actually several simple but effective options for her to avoid embarrassment.
http://www.audressforformal.com/media/catalog/product/cache/1/image/441x/17f82f742ffe127f42dca9de82fb58b1/a/u/audress-737002309.jpg
No doubt all methods to make the stain invisible are about covering it up, and what a girl can choose is what to be used as the cover. A brooch matching the design of her formal dress could be the best choice as it is available in various sizes and styles to not only hide the stain but also add glamour to her figure. A simple alternative to brooch is bowknot, which matches especially pretty well with cock-tail formal dresses. The wearer can also present others with her humanistic aspect by covering the stain with a support ribbon from a charity or non-profit organization. If she is certain that it is absolutely impossible to remove the stain, she can also choose to stich sequins or embroider flower patterns onto the stained part of the dress.

Choices mentioned above are good to stains on upper part of a formal dress, but what if the stain is in lower part, like the belly part or the skirt part? There are difficulties in dealing with such an annoying stain, but it is not completely impossible. Scarf or large shawl can be worn in a deliberate way so that a stain at anywhere from bust to upper belly can be covered beneath. When the stain is near the waistline, the wearer can make minor adjustment to her waistband to hide it. Wide ribbon belt of bright color in tune with the long formal dress will definitely beautify the formal dress while protecting wearer from revealing the imperfect part of hers dress.
http://www.audressforformal.com/media/catalog/product/cache/1/image/441x/17f82f742ffe127f42dca9de82fb58b1/a/d/ad292.jpg
As to a stain that happens to appear on the skirt of a formal dress, smarter ideas are needed to deal with it. A stain near the bottom of skirt can be covered with a patch of the same color and fabric with the formal dress, since others could hardly find out what is different with that part that is swinging all the time when the wearer is moving. To make the patch more invisible, the thread used to stich it onto the skirt should also be in the same color.

Now what remains is how to cover a stain on the part of skirt that everyone can see clearly. It may look weird with a pin flower or a patch at that part, so a slightly bigger alteration is necessary. It should be worth a try to add some furrows to the skirt so that the stain would be folded into invisible part of a furrow; or vine-shaped string-like decorative stuff could be pinned to wind from waist or even shoulders down to the bottom of skirt passing over the stained part. And if professional help is available, adding a tulle outskirt could also be a good choice to make the stain out of the vision of other attenders at the year 12 formal.

A corset is a type of undergarment that serves to support the bust and define the waistline. It is most often worn by women, but sometimes by men as well. Corsets may be worn to support the spine for medical reasons or to create a certain shape for aesthetic purposes. The corset was commonly worn by women in the Western world until the use of bras became more widespread in the 1920s and 1930s.

Corsets vary widely in their design as well as their purpose. Most are made of fabric, leather, or another flexible material and enforced with hard strips called boning. In the Victorian period, boning was usually whalebone, although steel was also used. Today, many corsets use plastic boning for a more lightweight feel. A corset typically laces up in the back in order to adjust the fit, although some models lace in the front. Some back-laced models also feature buttons or hooks on the front.

While the practice of wearing a corset, particularly during the Victorian era, often gets a bad rap, it is not harmful or uncomfortable if done correctly. Some wearers did and do take the corset to an extreme in a practice known as tightlacing, in which the waist may be reduced to around 15 inches (38 cm), and some have had ribs removed in order to create a smaller waist. However, such extremes are not widespread, and corsets do not typically create health problems or inhibit the wearer's physical activity if worn properly. When wearing a traditional corset, it is important to have it custom fitted in order to avoid health risks.
